home.title: UNDER CONSTRUCTION - Developing Identifiers for Heritage Collections
home.content:
This resource describes the different facets of developing persistent identifiers (PIDs) in the context of Heritage Collections.

Before you begin...

This resource is aimed at senior technical stakeholders within galleries, libraries, archives and museums to assist with developing requirements and advocacy for new services. Have a look at the [Read Me|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Read%20Me.html] section before getting started.

[##]

This resource will be revised in 2021 and maintained until the conclusion of the [Towards a National Collection|https://www.nationalcollection.org.uk] programme in 2025.

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.

Icons: Server, Protest, Robot, More information on [Freepik|https://www.freepik.com], Plus by Vectors Market, Book by Payungkead and Globe by turkkub on [flaticon|https://www.flaticon.com].

Aspects.title: Aspects for Developing Identifiers
Aspects.content:
This page contains links to the aspects for developing persistent identifiers for heritage collections. For more information about this resource, see [Read Me|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Read%20Me.html].

  • [Augment with existing IDs|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Augment.html]
  • Assign IDs which could be persistent
  • Commit to persisting IDs
  • Humanly resolvable PIDs
  • Machine readable PIDs
  • Globally resolvable PIDs

Augment.title: Augment with existing identifiers
Augment.content:
Externally-created persistent identifiers are included for items and entities within metadata

Explanation

PIDs such as Wikidata IDs, ISNIs, Getty URIs, DOIs, Gazetteer URIs and IDs from other collections can be added to collection management systems. These can be included for related collection items, an identifier for a collection item itself where it is represented in another identifier scheme and authority files.

Benefits

  • Links with other collections.
  • Reduces workload of creating institution specific authority files.

Dependencies

[Baseline|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Read%20Me.html] required.

Compatible PID Types

  • Wikidata IDs
  • Getty URIs
  • Gazetteer URIs
  • Digital Object Identifiers from other collections
  • Handles from other collections
  • ARKs from other collections
  • URIs from other collections

For more compatible identifiers, see Which persistent identifier does what?

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.
Augment.content right:
Examples

The Library of Congress provides links to other identifiers in its [names identifier file|http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79041870]

[National Galleries Scotland|https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/artists/paul-gauguin] and [Moma|https://www.moma.org/artists/5047] in New York integrate Getty ULAN records and Wikipedia data into their artistsâ€™ web pages.

Supporting Materials.title: Supporting Materials
Supporting Materials.content: This page contains links to supporting materials and guidance to help in using this resource.

Read Me.title: Read me - how to use this resource
Read Me.content:
Getting Started

The aspects are arranged in a general progression but a single institution would not have to implement all of these aspects.

Dependencies refer to other parts of this resource only. They mention the other aspects which would have had to have been implemented in order to implement that aspect.

Compatible PID types are included where the aspect describes an externally facing aspect of implementation.

All aspects require a baseline collections system to be in place.

The Baseline

Identifiers assigned within the metadata for physical items and/or digital objects. The identifiers are not globally unique, machine readable or resolvable. This is where we assume most users of this resource will be and the various facets build on this.

Explanation

This is what most organisations use now. These could be accession numbers, archive reference number, barcodes, internal database identifiers. The identifiers might be used in different systems but there is no computer interaction between systems using the identifier.

Benefits

You can use them to find items within your collection, however often they only work across one type of collection, e.g. you cannot search the museum collection management system using the archive reference number. Internal reporting is possible.

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.
Read Me.content right:
Examples

Any museum with a collection management system such Adlib, TMS, Emu etc. will meet this baseline level. Archives using a management system such as Calm. Libraries using a system such as Aleph or Alma.
